----- Original Message -----
From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>

> It seems the ideas put forward in the link above were not
> popular. Adding stuff to HTML doesn't seem like the right thing to do
> anyway.
>
> I've always wondered why an authentication response couldn't have an
> entity associated with it, either in the response body or referenced
> via some content-location like header.
Fundamentally, the user-agent (browser, spider, utility, etc.) is
responsible for placing the correct bits in the authentication header(s).
Displaying the entity associated with an authentication challenge is nice,
but without indicating that user input is meant as protocol-level
authentication, then the user-agent will not be able to manage that. That is
why adding stuff to HTML is necessary.

The alternative approach is that the server controls the lifetime of
authentication information - essentially cookie based.
Adding things to the protocol to support control over authentication
lifetime might be an approach that gives application authors control, but
provides visibility to user-agents (and intermediaries). The kinds of things
I'm thinking about are responses indicating 'forget auth for this realm' and
'remember this auth-token for this realm'. Cookies are a generalized form of
this, but you lose the visibility that there is security information in
there.
